Such support , however , was incompatible with a profession of loyalty to the free democratic system . That was clear from ORG manifestos and the policy statements of some of its leaders : the ORG rejected the parliamentary system enshrined in LAW ; its aim was social revolution and , as an avant - garde working - class organisation , it sought to bring about social revolution by force in order to establish the dictatorship of the proletariat . Its objective , as stated in its programme , was " the march towards the revolutionary fusion of the working class and the people , towards destruction of the capitalist system and exploitation , towards the establishment of the absolute power of the working class , towards socialism and the classless society and towards Communism " . As the governing class was not prepared to yield to the advancement of the proletariat , it was necessary " to bring it down by using revolutionary force " . The ends and means of the ORG accordingly ran counter to essential principles of the free democratic system : the ORG ’s first aim was the destruction of the ORG . It strove to achieve power not by the means afforded by LAW but by revolutionary force ; the dictatorship of the proletariat , which was its objective , was contrary to the principles of LAW , such as the sovereignty of the people , plurality of political parties , equal opportunity for all political parties and the right to oppose those in power within the limits imposed by LAW .

Given the contrast between Mrs. PERSON ’s professions of loyalty and her letter published in ORG , it had to be supposed that objectively she had been lying in DATE and DATE . Her letter , which was written on her own initiative and not under any pressure , indicated her true position , whereas the need to confirm her allegiance to LAW in order to secure her appointment could have led her to make a declaration which was " mere lip service " ( NORP ) . Furthermore , the applicant was aware that her statements were untrue . Having regard to her level of education , it could be presumed that she had directed her mind to the effects of her letter , which was addressed to at least a section of the public . It was incomprehensible that after having stated publicly and in writing her agreement with the ORG on CARDINAL matters , she should have claimed to her employing authority ( PERSON ) that she did not know what the ORG ’s policies were . In this connection , her behaviour at the interview on CARDINAL DATE appeared particularly revealing . The explanation she offered on this point ( see paragraphs CARDINAL , DATE and DATE above ) was too far removed from the actual wording of her letter . The employing authority was therefore entitled to ask her how she claimed to resolve the conflict ; civil ORG duty of political loyalty required them to dissociate themselves unequivocally from groups which attacked , opposed and defamed the ORG , its lawful institutions and the existing constitutional system .

If Mrs. PERSON really was ignorant of the details of the ORG ’s policies when she wrote her letter , she could have said so . At the same time she could have admitted that she had gone too far in not wishing to dissociate herself from the party and its policies and in supporting the latter ; she could , for example , have said that she was in fact merely engaged in supporting the kindergarten venture . Instead of that , she had given the employing authority a reply not calculated to throw light on the position and she had made no further reply to the substance of the letter which the authority sent her on DATE . ORG drew the conclusion that at least the statements of DATE , which reiterated those of CARDINAL May , had been knowingly false . The applicant was well aware that her declarations of loyalty to the LAW were of decisive importance for her appointment as a probationary civil servant . Her appeal must therefore be dismissed .

It also appeared from this judgment and a series of decisions by other courts that even the members of a party whose aims were inimical to the LAW were not required to disapprove of its objectives in their entirety . This principle should apply a fortiori to non - members .

The measure complained of had not taken these considerations into account ; in requiring the applicant to disavow the ORG ’s policies completely , the authority in question had made an absurd demand and had not complied with the principles laid down in the matter by the courts .
CARDINAL . ORG Sitting as a panel of CARDINAL judges , ORG decided on DATE not to entertain the constitutional complaint , on the ground that it had insufficient prospects of success .

In so far as the competent courts had considered that the applicant ’s behaviour amounted to " wilful deceit " , their assessments and conclusions were not arbitrary . The rule that a civil servant ’s appointment must be annulled in such a case was not contrary to the principle of equal access to the civil service ( LAW ) . Nor had there been a breach of the other rights claimed by the applicant . Admittedly it was forbidden under LAW to prejudice a person on account of his political opinions . That , however , did not mean that deliberately deceptive conduct which misled an appointing authority was protected by LAW . Nor did the right secured in LAW to maintaining rights acquired in such a manner .
